facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1963 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEALLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 2, 1960 of Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 1 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and ,order dated February 2, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 1 of 1955.

facts.text: Respondents are a firm constituted under a deed dated December 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-Respondents to this appeal are a firm companystituted under a deed dated December 12, 1947.

facts.text: Firm originally consisted of three partners: K. N. Damodara Mudaliar, A. Krishnaswami Mudaliar and V. Thangaraja Mudaliar.

anchor.surface_text: The firm originally companysisted of three partners K. N. Damodara Mudaliar, A. Krishnaswami Mudaliar and v. Thangaraja Mudaliar.

facts.text: K.N. Damodara Mudaliar acquired for the firm exploitation rights for Rs. 1,00,000/- for four years in film Apoorva Chinthamani for North Arcot, South Arcot, Chingleput districts and Pondicherry.

anchor.surface_text: K.N. Damodara Mudaliar acquired for the firm for Rs. 1,00,000/- the exploitation rights which were to ensure for four years in a cinematograph film Apoorva Chinthamani for the North Arcot, the South Arcot and the Chingleput districts and for Pondicherry.

facts.text: For period December 25, 1947 to August 2, 1948 (previous year for assessment year 1949-50), firm filed voluntary return declaring Rs. 28,643/- earned by exploitation of the film.

anchor.surface_text: For the period, December 25, 1.947 to August 2, 1948--which was the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1949-50the firm filed a voluntary return declaring that Rs. 28,643/were earned by the exploitation of the film.

facts.text: In statement, total receipts Rs. 1,46,849/-, debited Rs. 13,206/- expenses and Rs. 1,00,000/- for rights, no credit for unexpired rights at end of previous year.

anchor.surface_text: In the statement submitted by the firm the total receipts credited in the firms books were Rs. 1,46,849/-, and against that amount were debited Rs. 13,206/- as expenses and Rs. 1,00,000/- as the amount disbursed for acquiring the exploitation rights.

facts.text: On August 15, 1948, deed of dissolution executed, Damodara Mudaliar sold half interest effective August 6, 1948 for Rs. 2,000/- and retired.

anchor.surface_text: On August 15, 1948, a deed of dissolution of the partnership was executed, and Damodara Mudaliar sold with effect from August 6, 1948, his half interest in the assets of the partnership to Krishnaswami Mudaliar for Rs. 2,000/- and retired from the partnership.

facts.text: On August 27, 1948, trial balance-sheet showed cash Rs. 190/12/4, debit Krishnaswami Rs. 2,641/8/8, credits Damodara Rs. 1,888/2/11, Thangaraja Rs. 944/2/1.

anchor.surface_text: On August 27, 1948 a trial balance-sheet of the firms books of account was prepared showing a cash balance of Rs. 190/12/4, a debit against Krishnaswami Mudatiar for Rs. 2.641/8/8 and credits in favour of Damodara Mudaliar and Thangaraja Mudaliar respectively for Rs. 1,888/2/11 and Rs. 944/2/1.

facts.text: Krishnaswami Mudaliar, Thangaraja Mudaliar and V.S. Lakshmanan formed new partnership to exploit film for unexpired period.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Krishnaswami Mudaliar, Thangaraja Muidaliar and V. S. Lakshmanan  an outsider  formed themselves into another partnership to exploit the film for the unexpired period.

facts.text: Krishnaswami Mudaliar retired from new partnership on February 22, 1949 for Rs. 12,000/- his six sixteenth share.

anchor.surface_text: From this partnership Krishnaswami Mudaliar retired on February 22. 1949 agreeing to receive Rs. 12000/- for his six sixteenth share in the assets of the firm on the date of retirement.

facts.text: Second Additional Income-tax Officer, Vellore declined to accept net profit Rs. 28,643/-, estimated unexpired rights Rs. 65,000/-, computed net profits Rs. 93,642/- for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment of the respondent firm for the year 1949- 50 the Second Additional income-tax Officer, Vellore declined to accept the statement of account that the firm had earned till August 2, 1948, a net profit of only Rs. 28,643/- as truly representing the profits of the firm.

facts.text: Firm in appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner challenged valuation at Rs. 65,000/-, submitted Rs. 4,000/- true value based on Damodara's sale for Rs. 2,000/- half share.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the firm to the Appellate Assistant Com- missioner, the companyrectness of the estimated value of the ex- ploitation rights of the film at Rs. 65,000/ was alone chal- lenged and it was submitted that the sum of Rs. 4,000/- was the true value of the assets at the end of the previous year.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected contention, held valuation in dissolution deed dictated by extra-commercial considerations, confirmed Rs. 65,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Damodara Mudaliar the retiring partner having relinquished his rights representing half share for Rs. 2.000/- only. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the companytention, holding that the valuation of the exploitation rights for the unexpired period in the deed of dissolution dated August 15, 1948 was dictated by extra- companymercial companysiderations.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reduced valuation to Rs. 40,000/- as on August 2, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Even in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, the respondent firm merely companytended that the valuation of the exploitation rights for the unexpired period was excessive. The Tribunal partially upheld the plea, and reduced the valuation to Rs. 40.000/- as on August 2, 1948,

facts.text: High Court of Madras under s.66(2) referred question: Whether Tribunal justified in applying proviso to s.13 and confirming assessment on mercantile basis.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to an order issued by the High Court of Madras in a petition under s. 66 2  the Tribunal stated the case and referred the following question --- Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case the Tribunal was justified in applying the proviso to s. 13 of the Income- tax Act and in companyfirming the assessment on a mercantile basis of accounting.

facts.text: Madras High Court held assessee adopted cash system, Tribunal erred in discarding it for mercantile, answered question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it was open to the assessee to maintain accounts according to a recognised system of ac- companynting and the assessee having adopted the cash system of ,accounting, and the Tribunal having assigned numberreasons for discarding that system in the companyputation of the profits the Tribunal was in error in making the assessment on the basis of the mercantile system of accounting.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered April 16, 1964 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: Narayanaswamy and R. Gopalakrishnan, for respondent number. I and 3-6. April 16, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by. SHAH, J.-

facts.text: Firm maintained accounts on cash system, debited full acquisition cost, ignored closing stock value.

anchor.surface_text: Thereby in the companyputation of the profits of the business, the firm debited the amount paid for acquiring the rights of exploitation of the film, but did number take credit for the value of the unexpired exploitation rights at the end of the previous year.

facts.text: Expenses debited Rs. 18,206/-, total collections Rs. 1,46,849/-, net profit claimed Rs. 28,647/- after debiting Rs. 1,00,000/- acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: Note the facts an amount of Rs. 1,00,000/- was paid by the firm for acquiring a wasting asset, which was to be exploited for the benefit of the partnership. The price paid for acquiring the asset was debited as an outgoing. At the end of the year there was a total, companylection of Rs. 1,46,849/- by the exploitation of the asset. The expenses for carrying on the business amounted to Rs. 18,206 -.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Income-tax Officer entitled to value closing stock for proper computation of profits.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the High Court was in error in holding that because the assessee had maintained his accounts in the cash system it was number open to the Income- tax Officer to add to the receipts from the business the value of the stock-in-trade at the end of the year for the purpose of properly deducing the profits of the business for the year in question.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, question answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore must be allowed and the answer to the question referred to the High Court will be in the affirma- tive.

facts.text: Firm's method of accounting was not mercantile but cash or primarily cash.

anchor.surface_text: It is company- mon ground that the method of accounting was number mercantile. but was wholly or primarily cash.

facts.text: No challenge before AAC or Tribunal to applicability of proviso to s.13.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Tribunal the only plea raised was that the Income-tax Officer had erred in estimating the value of the unexpired exploitation rights at Rs. 65,000/-.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred as ITO entitled under proviso to s.13 to adjust for closing stock value even under cash system to properly deduce true profits.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer not bound by assessee's cash method of accounting that debits acquisition cost but ignores closing stock value; may add stock value under proviso to s.13.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the High Court was in error in holding that because the assessee had maintained his accounts in the cash system it was number open to the Income- tax Officer to add to the receipts from the business the value of the stock-in-trade at the end of the year for the purpose of properly deducing the profits of the business for the year in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee's method does not properly deduce profits without stock adjustment; proviso permits suitable basis including stock valuation.

holdings.text: In all trading cases, true profits cannot be properly deduced from any accounting system, cash or mercantile, without valuing opening and closing stock at cost or market price (lower).

anchor.surface_text: in all trading cases the true profits cannot be deduced from any system of maintaining accounts whether cash or mercantile, unless the opening and closing stocks are brought into the picture at companyt or market price whichever is lower

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary commercial accounting principles and precedents (Cock Russell, Whimster) require stock valuation for accurate annual profits regardless of system.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.13 empowers ITO to invoke alternative computation basis, including stock valuation, when assessee's method prevents proper deduction of profits.

anchor.surface_text: By applying the proviso to s. 13, they made the companyputation upon the basis and in the manner in which in their opinion profits would be properly deduced. That they were entitled to do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory duty under s.13 proviso to examine method and adjust if profits not properly deductible; applies to cash systems ignoring stock.

holdings.text: Exploitation rights in film are stock-in-trade and wasting asset requiring end-of-year valuation for profit computation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of business as trading venture in film rights demands stock treatment per commercial principles.

precedents.citation: Secretary, Board of Revenue, Madras v. Arunachalam Chettiar 1

anchor.surface_text: Secretary, Board of Revenue, Madras v. Arunachalam Chettiar 1 expressed the view that whatever may be the system of accounting adopted by an assessee, income assessable to tax means the income actually or constructively received

precedents.case_name: Secretary Board of Revenue Madras v Arunachalam Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: whatever may be the system of accounting adopted by an assessee, income assessable to tax means the income actually or constructively received and that the words of the charging section placed limits upon the succeeding sections

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Sarangpur Cotton Manufacturing Company Ltd, Ahmedabad 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Sarangpur Cotton Manufacturing Company Ltd, Ahmedabad 2 x x x the section relates to a method of accounting regularly employed by the assessee for his own purposes x x x and does not relate to a method

precedents.case_name: CIT Bombay v Sarangpur Cotton Manufacturing Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: s.13 relates to method of accounting regularly employed by assessee for own purposes, compulsory basis unless income cannot properly be deduced; duty of ITO to consider if profits can be properly deduced

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mcmillan Co. 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mcmillan Co. 2 the expression in the opinion of the Income-tax Officer in the proviso to s. 13 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, does not confer a mere discretionary power

precedents.cited_proposition: the expression 'in the opinion of the Income-tax Officer' imposes a statutory duty to examine the method of accounting and determine if income can properly be deduced

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Cock Bussell and Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Cock Bussell and Co. Ltd. 1 . Croom-Johnson J., in dealing with valuation of stock-in-trade for purposes of taxation observed there is no word in the statutes or rules

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v Cock Russell and Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: in computing profits of commercial concern, stock-in-trade at start and end must be taken into account; impossible to assess profits merely on receipts and payments

precedents.citation: Whimster Co. v. The Commissioner of Inland Revenue 2

anchor.surface_text: Reference may also be made to Whimster Co. v. The Commissioner of Inland Revenue 2 in which Lord President Clyde observed at p. 823- In computing the balance of profits and gains for the purposes of Income Tax

precedents.case_name: Whimster & Co v Commissioner of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: profits consist of difference between receipts and expenditure laid out to earn them; account must be consistent with ordinary principles of commercial accounting including stock at cost or market whichever lower

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. Messrs. Chari and Ram, Madura 1

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. Messrs. Chari and Ram, Madura 1 Rajamannar J., observed that stock-in-trade in hand is an essential item in the computation of the profits

precedents.case_name: CIT and EPT Madras v Chari and Ram Madura
precedents.cited_proposition: stock-in-trade in hand is an essential item in the computation of the profits for a period

precedents.citation: Spanish Prospecting Company Ltd. in re. 2

anchor.surface_text: Profits as observed by Fletcher-Moulton, L.J., in the Spanish Prospecting Company Ltd. in re. 2 . implies a comparison between the state of a business at two specific dates usually separated by an interval

precedents.case_name: Spanish Prospecting Company Ltd, In re
precedents.cited_proposition: profits implies comparison between state of business at two dates; ascertained by comparison of assets, increase represents profits

precedents.citation: The Naval Colliery Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Inland Revenue 1
